stem: The nurse in a men's health clinic is reviewing records for four male clients. Based on the documentation in the Men's Health Screening Tracker, match each client with the most appropriate priority screening intervention.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: 45y/o African American male. Father was diagnosed with prostate cancer at age 50. 
Patient B: 52y/o Caucasian male. Average risk for all cancers. 
Patient C: 66y/o male. Former smoker (1.5 packs per day for 30 years). 
Patient D: 47y/o male. Reports changes in bowel habits and rectal bleeding.

tabs.title: Men's Health Screening Tracker
tabs.content:

tabs.title: Vital Signs & BMI
tabs.content: All patients are stable. Patient C has a palpable, pulsating mass in the periumbilical area.

rows.text: Prostate Specific Antigen (PSA) and Digital Rectal Exam (DRE)
Annual Low-Dose CT (LDCT) for Lung Cancer

rationale.correct: Prostate screening (r1) should be discussed starting at 45 for high-risk groups like African Americans or those with family history (c1). AAA screening (r2) is a one-time ultrasound for men aged 65-75 who have EVER smoked (c2). Routine colonoscopy (r3) starts at age 45 for all average-risk individuals (c3). Lung cancer screening (r4) is also required for smoking history (c2).
clinicalPearls: AAA screening is specifically for MALES with SMOKING history.
African American men have the highest mortality from prostate cancer and should be screened earlier.
A 'pulsating mass' in the abdomen is a classic AAA indicator.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking that a 45-year-old is 'too young' for a PSA test.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If they have high-risk factors (Race/Family), 45 is the recommended discussion age.
